column4: when i update or install any software in my ubuntu 10.04 through software centre or synaptics the first package gets downloaded recursively and ultimaltely nothing gets installed moreover sometines it says check your internet connections and sometimes package not found
Check your network connection - that seems to be part of the issue mate.
my network is fine

I didn't say your NETWORK was not fine, I'm saying check your connection settings in the Network Manager - you can also try in a terminal to do: sudo apt-get update => then see what the connectivity is like first hand.
i ran sudo apt-get update also with parameters --fix-broken and --fix-missing everything went fine
but ya sometimes it do gie issues
wat to do???
I'd do everything from the terminal if the graphical package manager doesn't cut the mustard - or start troubleshooting your actual network connection - not the network - but the connection.
how???
HOw...um...what? To update and install packages from the term? Or how to troubleshoot the network connection?
Troubleshoot network connection

Edit the connection. Change the settings - or at least make SURE the settings are correct for your network. YOu can always add in an external DNS server for giggles and grins to see if that helps you out - cuz if the package manager cannot resolve a server's name, it's not going to be able to update, right?
i am studying in a college and settingss are default to match up also this is the first of its kind that i have encounterd also the prob persists in command line
90% of what you just said doesn't make sense.
the prob persists even when i use terminal
i am using default settings
Mate, try changing some settings - as I said, add an external DNS server to your network connection and see if that makes a differences. Try 139.130.4.5 for instance.
how to do that
Right click network manager icon, choose edit connnections -> yadda yadda yadda
then
Edit the network connection, add 139.130.4.5 to your normal DNS server list - restart the connection, try again doing an update.
